title: Richie Stotts
text:
Richard Eugene Stotts (born 27 October 1953) (better known as Richie Stotts) is a musician, who was the first guitarist and one of the founding members of the punk/metal group <a href="Plasmatics">Plasmatics</a>.
In 1978, Richie was among the earliest musicians to sport a <a href="Mohawk%20hairstyle">Mohawk</a>,
taking inspiration from the <a href="Travis%20Bickle">Travis Bickle</a> character in the movie "<a href="Taxi%20Driver">Taxi Driver</a>". In an effort to keep up with his constantly outrageous stagemate <a href="Wendy%20O.%20Williams">Wendy O. Williams</a>, he would also <a href="Cross-dressing">cross dress</a> in various items like a <a href="Nurse%20uniform">nurse's uniform</a>, a <a href="Tutu%20%28clothing%29">tutu</a>, a <a href="wedding%20dress">wedding dress</a> and a <a href="French%20maid">French maid</a>.
After leaving the Plasmatics in 1984, Richie pursued a solo career with his band <a href="King%20Flux">King Flux</a> and a graduate degree in <a href="Geology">Geology</a>.
Richie appears in a brief cameo in "<a href="9%C2%BD%20Weeks">9½ Weeks</a>", movie with <a href="Kim%20Basinger">Kim Basinger</a>. He's recognizable by the blonde mohawk and chainsaw tattoo in a party scene.
He was a great friend of <a href="Joey%20Ramone">Joey Ramone</a> and was one of several speakers at a <a href="CBGB">CBGB's</a> all-star tribute put on by <a href="Mickey%20Leigh">Mickey Leigh</a>, Joey's brother, in 2001. <a href="Dee%20Dee%20Ramone">Dee Dee Ramone</a> was also a friend, the two composed "Punishment Fits the Crime" which appeared on the 1989 "<a href="Brain%20Drain%20%28album%29">Brain Drain</a>" album by the <a href="Ramones">Ramones</a>.
In 2004, he collaborated with singer-songwriter and wife Carla Lother on several songs for her "100 Lovers" album.
